ğŸ“– Vol 1: Invocations and Supplications
[112] Hadith: Whoever says when he goes to his bed: 'I seek forgiveness from Allah the Great, who there is no god except He, the Living, the Self-Subsisting (Al-Hayy Al-Qayyum), and I repent to Him' three times, Allah will forgive his sins even if they were like the foam of the sea. The hadith was reported by Al-Tirmidhi from the narration of Abu Sa'id and he said: 'It is strange (gharib), we do not know it except from the narration of Abdullah ibn Al-Walid Al-Wasafi.' I say: Al-Wasafi, even though he is weak, he was followed in this by 'Issam ibn Qudamah, and he is trustworthy. And Al-Bukhari reported it in Al-Tarikh without his saying 'when he goes to his bed' and his saying 'three times'.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
And He made them know that nothing of what they conceal and what they reveal is hidden from Him, and He warned them that He might seize them suddenly while they are unaware, so He said: "They await not but a single blast which will seize them while they are disputing. Then they will not be able to make a bequest, nor will they return to their families." And prayers and peace be upon Muhammad, His messenger, under whose banner the prophets march, and upon his family and his companions, the guided leaders, and the pleased masters, a prayer whose number equals the number of what has been of Allah's creation and what will be, and the first and the last attain its blessing, and abundant peace. Then after, indeed anger is a flame of fire kindled from the fire of Allah that is ignited, which rises upon the hearts (Af'idah), and it is hidden in the folds of the heart (Fu'ad). The hiding of embers under ashes, and it is extracted by the concealed arrogance in the heart (Qalb) of every obstinate tyrant, like extracting fire from stone with iron, and it has been revealed to the observers with the light of certainty (Yaqin), that a vein in the human being extends to the accursed Satan, so whoever is provoked by the fire of anger has strengthened in him the kinship of Satan when he said: "You created me from fire and created him from clay." For the nature of clay is stillness and dignity, and the nature of fire is blazing and flaming, and movement and agitation, and from the outcomes of anger are malice (Haqd) and envy (Hasad), and by them perished whoever perished and corrupted whoever corrupted, and their source is a morsel; if it is rectified, the entire body is rectified with it, and if malice (Haqd) and envy (Hasad) and anger (Ghadd) are present.

a.g: It is He who forms you in the wombs however He wills. There is no deity except Him, the Exalted in Might, the Wise.

It is He who has sent down to you, [O Muhammad], the Book; in it are verses [that are] precise - they are the foundation of the Book - and others unspecific. As for those in whose hearts is deviation [from truth], they will follow that of it which is unspecific, seeking discord and seeking an interpretation [suitable to them]. And no one knows its [true] interpretation except Allah. But those firm in knowledge say, "We believe in it. All [of it] is from our Lord." And no one will be reminded except those of understanding.

And knowledge of certainty (Ilm al-Yaqin) also has a rank, even if it is below the eye of certainty (Ayn al-Yaqin). ğŸ“– Vol 1: Book of Knowledge
Indeed, know that knowledge [â€˜ilm] by this consideration is of three divisions: A division that is blameworthy in its little and its much; and a division that is praiseworthy in its little and its much, and the more it is, the better and more excellent it is; and a division wherein the sufficient measure is praised, but the surplus and exhaustive pursuit in it is not praisedâ€”and it is like the states of the body. For among them is that which is praised in its little and its much, like health and beauty; and among them is that which is blameworthy in its little and its much, like ugliness and bad character; and among them is that wherein moderation is praised, like the spending of wealth, for extravagance is not praised in it, though it is a form of spending; and like courage, for recklessness is not praised in it, though it is of the genus of courage. So it is with knowledge. The blameworthy division of it, in its little and its much, is that which has no benefit in religion [din] or in this world [dunya], for in it is harm that overcomes its benefit, like the knowledge of magic, talismans, and astrology. Some of it has no benefit at all, and to devote one's lifetimeâ€”which is the most precious thing a human possessesâ€”to it is waste, and wasting the precious is blameworthy. And some of it contains harm that outweighs what is imagined to be gained from it in fulfilling worldly desires, for that is not considered in comparison to the harm that results from it. As for the division that is praiseworthy to the utmost limits of exhaustive pursuit, it is the knowledge [maâ€˜rifa] of God, Exalted is He, and His attributes, His actions, His way [sunnah] in His creation, and His wisdom in arranging the Hereafter [akhirah] upon this world [dunya]. For this is knowledge sought for its own sake and to attain through it the happiness of the Hereafter. To expend one's utmost capability in it to the extreme of effort is a shortcoming from the limit of what is obligatory, for it is an ocean whose depths are not reached. The seekers only circle upon its shores and its edges according to what is made easy for them. None have plunged into its depths except the Prophets, the saints [awliyaâ€™], and those firmly grounded in knowledge [al-rasikhun fi al-â€˜ilm], differing in their degrees according to the difference in their strength and the varying decree of God, Exalted is He, concerning them. This is the treasured knowledge [al-â€˜ilm al-maknun] which is not written in books. What aids in becoming alert to it is learning and observing the states of the scholars of the Hereafterâ€”as their signs will comeâ€”this in the beginning of the matter. And what aids in it in the end is striving [mujahadah], spiritual discipline [riyadah], purifying the heart [qalb], and emptying it from the attachments of this world [dunya], and emulating therein the Prophets and the saints, so that from it may become clear to every seeker of it according to the measure of provision [rizq], not according to the measure of effort. But there is no dispensing in it from exertion [ijtihad], for striving [mujahadah] is the key to guidance [hidayah]; there is no key to it other than it. As for the sciences wherein only a specific measure is praised, they are the sciences we mentioned among the communal obligations [faraâ€™id al-kifayat]. For in every science of them there is a limit, which is the minimum; and a moderation, which is the middle; and an exhaustive pursuit beyond that moderation which has no end until the end of one's life. So be one of two men: either occupied with yourself, or free for others after being free from yourself. And beware of occupying yourself with what rectifies others before rectifying yourself. If you are the one occupied with yourself, then occupy yourself only with the knowledge that is an obligation upon you according to what your state requires, and what pertains to it from the outward actions, like learning the prayer, purification, and fasting. Yet the most important, which everyone has neglected, is the knowledge of the attributes of the heart [qalb], and what among them is praiseworthy and what is blameworthy, for no human is free from blameworthy attributes like greed, envy, ostentation, arrogance, self-admiration, and their sistersâ€”all of which are destroyers. And neglecting them is from the obligations, while occupying oneself with outward actions resembles occupying oneself with plastering the exterior of the body when afflicted with scabies and boils, while being negligent in expelling the morbid matter by cupping and purging. The superficial scholars [hashwiyyat al-â€˜ulamaâ€™] point to outward actions, just as the methodical physicians point to plastering the exterior of the body. But the scholars of the Hereafter point only to purifying the interior [batin] and cutting off the sources of evil by corrupting their roots and uprooting their plantings from the heart [qalb]. The majority have resorted to outward actions over purifying the hearts due to the ease of the actions of the limbs and the perceived difficulty of the actions of the hearts, just as one who finds it difficult to drink bitter medicines resorts to plastering the exterior. Thus, he continues to toil in plastering while the morbid matter increases and the diseases multiply upon him. If you are a desirer of the Hereafter [akhirah], a seeker of salvation, and a fugitive from eternal destruction, then occupy yourself with the knowledge of the inward maladies and their treatment, as we have detailed in the Quarter of the Destroyers.

a.g: Indeed, those who disbelieve - never will their wealth or their children avail them against Allah at all. And it is they who are fuel for the Fire.
[Theirs is] like the custom of the people of Pharaoh and those before them. They denied Our signs, so Allah seized them for their sins. And Allah is severe in penalty.
Say to those who disbelieve, "You will be overcome and gathered together to Hell, and wretched is the resting place."

Already there has been for you a sign in the two armies which met - one fighting in the cause of Allah and another of disbelievers. They saw them [to be] twice their [own] number by [their] eyesight. But Allah supports with His victory whom He wills. Indeed in that is a lesson for those of vision.

Beautified for people is the love of that which they desire - of women and sons, heaped-up sums of gold and silver, fine branded horses, and cattle and tilled land. That is the enjoyment of worldly life, but Allah has with Him the best return.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of the World
Indeed, God the Exalted has mentioned seven of them in a single verse, saying: "Beautified for people is the love of desires [shahawat]â€”from women and children, and heaped-up treasures of gold and silver, and branded horses, and cattle and tilled land. That is the enjoyment of the life of the world [hayat al-dunya]." Then He reduced it in another verse to five, saying, the Mighty and Majestic: "Know that the life of the world [al-hayat al-dunya] is but play and amusement, and adornment, and mutual boasting among you, and rivalry in increase of wealth and children." Then He the Exalted reduced it in another place to two, saying the Exalted: "And the life of the world [al-hayat al-dunya] is nothing but play and amusement." Then He reduced it all to one in another place, saying: "And restrain the soul [al-nafs] from desire [al-hawa]; indeed, Paradise is the abode." For "desire" [al-hawa] is a term that gathers all the shares of the soul [al-nafs] in the world [al-dunya]; therefore, asceticism [zuhd] should be in it.

And Allah the Exalted mentioned in one verse seven of them, saying: "Adorned for people is the love of desires from women and children and heaped-up measures of gold and silver and branded horses and cattle and tilled land. That is the enjoyment of the life of the world." Then He reduced it in another verse to five, saying the Mighty and Majestic: "Know that the life of the world is play and amusement and adornment and boasting among you and increase in wealth and children." Then He reduced it in another place to two, saying the Exalted: "And the life of the world is nothing but play and amusement." Vol 4: Watchfulness and Self-Examination
And He (Exalted) said: 'On the Day when every Soul (Nafs) will find what it did of good present, and what it did of evil, it will wish that between it and that (evil) were a distant period. And Allah warns you of His Self (Nafs).' And He (Exalted) said: 'And know that Allah knows what is in your souls (Anfus), so beware of Him.' So the possessors of insight from among the servants recognized that Allah (Exalted) is lying in wait for them, and that they will be scrutinized in the accounting and will be demanded with the weight of an atom from the passing thoughts (Khatarat) and glances. And they realized that nothing will save them from these dangers except adhering to self-accounting (Muhasaba) and sincerity in self-observation (Muraqaba) and demanding from the Soul (Nafs) in breaths and movements, and accounting it for passing thoughts (Khatarat) and glances. For whoever accounts his Soul (Nafs) before being accounted for, his accounting on the Day of Resurrection (Qiyamah) will be lightened, and his answer will be present at the questioning, and his return and outcome will be good. And whoever does not account his Soul (Nafs), his regrets will persist, and his standings in the plains of the Day of Resurrection (Qiyamah) will be prolonged, and his evil deeds will lead him to disgrace and contempt.

And Allah warns you of Himself, and Allah is Kind to the servants.' He said: So I sat behind him listening to his speech while he was repeating this verse, when he cried out a cry and fell unconscious. I said: Woe is me, this is for my misery. Then I waited for his recovery, and he recovered after an hour, and I heard him saying: I seek refuge in You from the station of the liars, I seek refuge in You from the deeds of the idle, I seek refuge in You from the turning away of the heedless. Then he said: To You have humbled the Hearts (Qulub) of the fearful, and to You have fled the hopes of the deficient, and to Your greatness have submitted the Hearts (Qulub) of the knowers. Then he shook his hand and said: What is mine with the world, and what is the world's, and what do I have upon you, O world, with your sons of kind and thousands of your bliss to your lovers? So go, and with them deceive. Then he said: Where are the past generations and the people of the bygone eras? In the dust they decay and upon time they perish. So I called to him: O servant of Allah, I am from today behind you waiting for your leisure. He said: And how can one be at leisure who hastens the times and they hasten him, fearing their precedence by death to his Soul (Nafs), or how can one be at leisure whose days have gone and his sins remain? Then he said: You are for it and for every hardship I expect its descent, then for it from me an hour. And he recited: 'And there will appear to them from Allah what they had not taken into account.' Then he cried out another cry more severe than the first and fell unconscious. I said: His Spirit (Ruh) has departed. So I approached him, and behold, he was convulsing, then he recovered and was saying: Who am I? What is my significance? ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
For the origin of this delusion (Ghurur) is ignorance of Allah and His attributes, for whoever knows Him does not feel secure from His plotting (Makr) nor is deceived by such false imaginings, and looks to Pharaoh, Haman, and Korah and to the kings of the earth and what befell themâ€”how Allah initially bestowed favors upon them then utterly destroyed them! So Allah the Exalted said: "Do you perceive any of them?" [Quran 69:8]. And Allah the Exalted has warned against His plotting (Makr) and gradual leading astray (Istidraj), saying: "So none feels secure from the plotting (Makr) of Allah except the losing people" [Quran 7:99], and He said: "And they plotted a plot, and We plotted a plot, while they perceive not" [Quran 27:50], and He the Mighty and Majestic said: "And they plotted and Allah plotted, and Allah is the best of plotters (Al-Makirin)" [Quran 3:54], and He said: "Indeed, they are planning a plan, and I am planning a plan. So allow time for the disbelievers. Leave them awhile" [Quran 86:15-17]. Just as it is not permissible for the negligent servant to infer from the master's neglect of him and enabling him with blessings that the master loves him, rather he should beware that this might be plotting (Makr) and scheming from him, even though the master did not warn him of his own plotting (Makr), then how much more must this be in the case of Allah the Exalted, with His warning of gradual leading astray (Istidraj), is more appropriate. Therefore, whoever feels secure from the plotting (Makr) of Allah is deluded (Mughtar), and the origin of this delusion (Ghurur) is that he inferred from worldly blessings that he is honorable with that Bestower, and it is possible that this is evidence of degradation, but that possibility does not agree with the desire (Hawa), so Satan, by means of the desire (Hawa), inclines the Heart (Qalb) toward what accompanies it, which is believing that it indicates honor, and this is the limit of delusion (Ghurur).

a.g: [Mention] when Allah said, "O Jesus, indeed I will take you and raise you to Myself and purify you from those who disbelieve and make those who follow you [in submission to Allah alone] superior to those who disbelieve until the Day of Resurrection. Then to Me is your return, and I will judge between you concerning that in which you used to differ.
And as for those who disbelieved, I will punish them with a severe punishment in this world and the Hereafter, and they will have no helpers."
But as for those who believed and did righteous deeds, He will give them in full their rewards, and Allah does not like the wrongdoers.
This is what We recite to you, [O Muhammad], of [Our] verses and the precise [and wise] message.
Indeed, the example of Jesus to Allah is like that of Adam. He created Him from dust; then He said to him, "Be," and he was.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
And it suffices him to know the meaning of one verse in the Book of Allah, for the Quran is the knowledge of the first and the last for whom his insight has been opened. And He, the Exalted, has said: "Woe to man! What has made him reject? From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop He created him and proportioned him. Then He made the way easy for him. Then He causes him to die and puts him in a grave. Then when He wills, He will resurrect him." This verse points to the first creation of the human being, which is that he was not a thing mentioned, and he was in the realm of non-existence for ages, rather his non-existence had no beginning. And what is more vile and less than obliteration and non-existence? And he was like that in pre-eternity. Then Allah created him from the most vile of things, then from the filthiest of them, for indeed He created him from dust, then from a sperm-drop, then from a clinging clot, then from a lump of flesh, then He made him bones, then He clothed the bones with flesh. This was the beginning of his existence when he became a thing mentioned. So he did not become a thing mentioned except while being upon the vilest of descriptions and attributes! For he was not created in his beginning complete, rather He created him as an inanimate dead thing that does not hear, nor see, nor feel, nor move, nor speak, nor grasp, nor perceive, nor know. So He began with his death before his life, and with his weakness before his strength, and with his ignorance before his knowledge, and with his blindness before his sight, and with his deafness before his hearing, and with his muteness before his speech, and with his misguidance before his guidance, and with his poverty before his wealth, and with his incapacity before his ability. This is the meaning of His saying: "From what thing did We create the human being? From a mixed sperm-drop." And the meaning of His saying: "Has there come upon man a period of time when he was not a thing mentioned? Indeed, We created man from a mixed sperm-drop to test him." Likewise, He created him first, then bestowed favor upon him, saying: "Then He made the way easy for him." And this points to what was facilitated for him during the period of his life until death. And likewise He said: "From a mixed sperm-drop We test him, so We made him hearing and seeing. Indeed, We guided him to the way, either grateful or ungrateful." And its meaning is that He gave him life after he was an inanimate dead thing, dust first and a sperm-drop second, and made him hear after he was deaf, and gave him sight after he was lacking vision, and strengthened him after weakness, and gave him knowledge after ignorance, and guided him after misguidance, and enriched him after poverty, and enabled him after incapacity. So if the human being knows himself with this knowledge, he knows that nothing befits him except humility, lowliness, and abasement. And if he knows his Lord, he knows that nothing befits greatness and pride except Allah. As for knowing his Lord and His majesty and glory, the discussion about it is lengthy, and it is the ultimate knowledge of unveiling (Mukashafa). And as for knowing himself, it is also lengthy, but we mention from that what benefits in arousing humility and lowliness. And it suffices him to know the meaning of one verse in the Book of Allah, for the Quran is the knowledge of the first and the last for whom his insight has been opened. And He, the Exalted, has said: "Indeed, the example of Jesus to Allah is like that of Adam. He created him from dust; then He said to him, 'Be,' and he was."

a.g: Indeed, this is the true narration. And there is no deity except Allah. And indeed, Allah is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
But if they turn away, then indeed - Allah is Knowing of the corrupters.

Say, "O People of the Scripture, come to a word that is equitable between us and you - that we will not worship except Allah and not associate anything with Him and not take one another as lords instead of Allah." But if they turn away, then say, "Bear witness that we are Muslims [submitting to Him]."
O People of the Scripture, why do you argue about Abraham while the Torah and the Gospel were not revealed until after him? Then will you not reason?
Here you are - those who have argued about that of which you have [some] knowledge, but why do you argue about that of which you have no knowledge? And Allah knows, while you know not.
Abraham was neither a Jew nor a Christian, but he was one inclining toward truth, a Muslim [submitting to Allah]. And he was not of the polytheists.

Indeed, the most worthy of Abraham among the people are those who followed him [in submission to Allah] and this prophet, and those who believe [in his message]. And Allah is the ally of the believers.
A faction of the people of the Scripture wish they could mislead you. But they do not mislead except themselves, and they perceive [it] not.
O People of the Scripture, why do you disbelieve in the verses of Allah while you witness [to their truth]?
O People of the Scripture, why do you confuse the truth with falsehood and conceal the truth while you know [it]?

And a faction of the People of the Scripture say [to each other], "Believe in that which was revealed to the believers at the beginning of the day and reject it at its end that perhaps they will abandon their religion,

And do not trust except those who follow your religion." Say, "Indeed, the [true] guidance is the guidance of Allah. [Do you fear] lest someone be given [knowledge] like you were given or that they would [thereby] argue with you before your Lord?" Say, "Indeed, [all] bounty is in the hand of Allah - He grants it to whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing and Wise."
He selects for His mercy whom He wills. And Allah is the possessor of great bounty.

And among the People of the Scripture is he who, if you entrust him with a great amount [of wealth], he will return it to you. And among them is he who, if you entrust him with a [single] silver coin, he will not return it to you unless you are constantly standing over him [demanding it]. That is because they say, "There is no blame upon us concerning the unlearned." And they speak untruth about Allah while they know [it].
But yes, whoever fulfills his commitment and fears Allah - then indeed, Allah loves those who fear Him.

Indeed, those who exchange the covenant of Allah and their [own] oaths for a small price will have no share in the Hereafter, and Allah will not speak to them or look at them on the Day of Resurrection, nor will He purify them; and they will have a painful punishment.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Earning a Livelihood
If praising the merchandise with truth is disliked because it is superfluous (Fudul) that does not increase in provision (Rizq), then the severity in the matter of the oath is not hidden. It has been narrated from Yunus bin 'Ubayd - and he was a silk merchant - that silk was requested from him for purchase, so his servant brought out the remnants of silk, spread it, looked at it and said: 'O Allah, grant us Paradise.' He said to his servant: 'Return it to its place' and did not sell it, fearing that this might be an allusion to praising the merchandise. Such are those who traded in this world (Dunya) and did not waste their religion (Deen) in their trades, but rather knew that the profit of the Hereafter (Akhirah) is more worthy of seeking than the profit of this world. The second is to reveal all defects of the sold item, both hidden and apparent, and not conceal anything from them, for that is obligatory. If he conceals it, he is an oppressor (Zalim), a deceiver (Ghash), and deception is forbidden, and he is abandoning sincerity (Nus'h) in the transaction, and sincerity is obligatory. Whenever he shows the better side of the garment and hides the other, he is a deceiver. Likewise, if he displays the garments in dark places, and likewise if he displays the better one of the pair of shoes or sandal and the like. What indicates the prohibition of deception is what has been narrated: He (peace be upon him) passed by a man selling food, and it pleased him, so he put his hand in it and saw dampness. He said: 'What is this?' He said: 'It was affected...'

a.g: Nor could he order you to take the angels and prophets as lords. Would he order you to disbelief after you had been Muslims?

And [recall, O People of the Scripture], when Allah took the covenant of the prophets, [saying], "Whatever I give you of the Scripture and wisdom and then there comes to you a messenger confirming what is with you, you [must] believe in him and support him." [Allah] said, "Have you acknowledged and taken upon that My commitment?" They said, "We have acknowledged it." He said, "Then bear witness, and I am with you among the witnesses."
And whoever turned away after that - they were the defiantly disobedient.
So is it other than the religion of Allah they desire, while to Him have submitted [all] those within the heavens and earth, willingly or by compulsion, and to Him they will be returned?

Say, "We have believed in Allah and in what was revealed to us and what was revealed to Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, and the Descendants, and in what was given to Moses and Jesus and to the prophets from their Lord. We make no distinction between any of them, and we are Muslims [submitting] to Him."
And whoever desires other than Islam as religion - never will it be accepted from him, and he, in the Hereafter, will be among the losers.
How shall Allah guide a people who disbelieved after their belief and had witnessed that the Messenger is true and clear signs had come to them? And Allah does not guide the wrongdoing people.
Those - their recompense will be that upon them is the curse of Allah and the angels and the people, all together,

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Book of Knowledge
And in another report: 'Whoever deceives my community, upon him is the curse of Allah and the angels and all the people. It was said: O Messenger of Allah, and what is deceiving your community? He said: That he innovates a religious innovation (bid'ah) and imposes it upon the people.' And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Indeed Allah the Exalted has an angel who calls out every day: Whoever opposes the tradition (sunnah) of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, will not attain his intercession.' And the example of the one who commits a crime against the religion by innovating what contradicts the tradition (sunnah) compared to one who commits a sin is like the example of one who disobeys the king in the heart of his kingdom compared to one who disobeys his command in a specific service, and that may be forgiven for him, but as for in the heart of the kingdom, no. And some scholars said: What the predecessors (salaf) spoke about, silence about it is ignorance, and what the predecessors (salaf) were silent about, speaking about it is affectation. And another said: The truth is heavy; whoever exceeds it oppresses, whoever falls short of it is deficient, and whoever stands with it is content. And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Adhere to the middle path to which the elevated returns and from which the follower ascends.' And Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: Misguidance has sweetness in the hearts (qulub) of its people. Allah the Exalted said: 'And leave those who take their religion as play and amusement' (Al-An'am: 70). And He said: 'Is he whose evil deed is made attractive to him so that he sees it as good?' (Fatir: 8). So everything that was innovated after the companions, may Allah be pleased with them, that exceeds the measure of necessity and need is from play and amusement.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Status and Ostentation
Look how the ignorant have turned and fallen on their faces like the falling of the blind, so they turned to seeking perfection of power through status and wealth, which is the perfection that does not remain safe and even if it remains safe, it has no permanence, and they turned away from the perfection of freedom and knowledge which, when attained, becomes eternal with no cessation. And these are the ones who have purchased the worldly life in exchange for the Hereafter, so indeed no punishment is lightened for them nor are they given respite, and they are the ones who did not understand His saying, the Exalted: 'Wealth and children are adornment of the worldly life, but the enduring righteous deeds are better with your Lord for reward and better for hope.' So knowledge and freedom are the enduring righteous deeds which remain as perfection in the Soul (Nafs), and wealth and status are what perish in proximity, and it is as Allah, the Exalted, has likened it where He said: 'The example of worldly life is like water which We send down from the sky...' the verse. And He, the Exalted, said: 'And present to them the example of the worldly life as water which We send down from the sky...' until His saying: '...then it becomes dry debris scattered by the winds.' And everything that the winds of death scatter is the flower of the worldly life, and everything that death does not cut off is the enduring righteous deeds.

Indeed, those who reject the message after their belief and then increase in disbelief - never will their [claimed] repentance be accepted, and they are the ones astray.

Indeed, those who disbelieve and die while they are disbelievers - never would the [whole] capacity of the earth in gold be accepted from one of them if he would [seek to] ransom himself with it. For those there will be a painful punishment, and they will have no helpers.
Never will you attain the good [reward] until you spend [in the way of Allah] from that which you love. And whatever you spend - indeed, Allah is Knowing of it.

a.g: All food was lawful to the Children of Israel except what Israel had made unlawful to himself before the Torah was revealed. Say, [O Muhammad], "So bring the Torah and recite it, if you should be truthful."
And whoever invents about Allah untruth after that - then those are [truly] the wrongdoers.
Say, "Allah has told the truth. So follow the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth; and he was not of the polytheists."
Indeed, the first House [of worship] established for mankind was that at Makkah - blessed and a guidance for the worlds.

In it are clear signs [such as] the standing place of Abraham. And whoever enters it shall be safe. And [due] to Allah from the people is a pilgrimage to the House - for whoever is able to find thereto a way. But whoever disbelieves - then indeed, Allah is free from need of the worlds.

And as for when there is wealth of doubtful nature (Shubha) that possibly could be permissible (Halal), if he does not remove it from his possession, the Pilgrimage (Hajj) becomes obligatory upon him because its being permissible is possible, and the Pilgrimage (Hajj) is not waived except due to poverty, and his poverty has not been confirmed. And Allah the Exalted has said: 'And to Allah is incumbent upon the people the Pilgrimage (Hajj) of the House for whoever is able to find a way to it.' And if it becomes obligatory upon him to give in charity (Sadaqah) what exceeds his need when the suspicion of its prohibition (Tahrim) predominates in his estimation, then the Obligatory Alms (Zakat) is more deserving of being obligatory. And if an expiation (Kaffarah) becomes obligatory upon him, then let him combine fasting (Sawm) and freeing a slave (Itq) to be purified with certainty. And some people have said that fasting (Sawm) becomes obligatory upon him without feeding (It'am) since he does not have known affluence. And Al-Muhasibi said that feeding (It'am) suffices him. And what we choose is that for every doubtful matter (Shubha) we have ruled the obligation of avoiding it and made obligatory upon him to remove it from his possession because the probability of prohibition (Haram) is predominant according to what we have mentioned. So upon him is combining fasting (Sawm) and feeding (It'am). As for fasting (Sawm), it is because he is legally bankrupt (Muflis). And as for feeding (It'am), it is because giving in charity (Sadaqah) of the entirety has become obligatory upon him, and it is possible that it belongs to him, so the obligation from the perspective of expiation (Kaffarah) becomes...

a.g: Say, "O People of the Scripture, why do you disbelieve in the verses of Allah while Allah is Witness over what you do?"

Say, "O People of the Scripture, why do you avert from the way of Allah those who believe, seeking to make it [seem] deviant, while you are witnesses [to the truth]? And Allah is not unaware of what you do."
O you who have believed, if you obey a party of those who were given the Scripture, they would turn you back, after your belief, [to being] unbelievers.
And how could you disbelieve while to you are being recited the verses of Allah and among you is His Messenger? And whoever holds firmly to Allah has [indeed] been guided to a straight path.
O you who have believed, fear Allah as He should be feared and do not die except as Muslims [in submission to Him].

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Sama and Wajd
Indeed, the word of the Almighty: "Fear Allah [taqwa] as He should be feared." As for the first, it is the fear of the general creation, and it is attained by the fundamental faith in Paradise and Hell, and that they are two recompenses for obedience and disobedience. Its weakness is due to heedlessness [ghafla] and the weakness of faith. Heedlessness is only removed by reminder and admonition, and by persistent reflection on the terrors of the Day of Resurrection and the varieties of punishment in the Hereafter. It is also removed by looking upon those who fear, keeping their company, and witnessing their states. If witnessing is missed, then hearing is not devoid of effect. As for the second, which is the higher, it is that Allah is the One fearedâ€”meaning that the servant fears the veil [hijab] from Him and hopes for proximity to Him. Dhu al-Nun, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "The fear of Hell, in the presence of the fear of separation, is like a drop dripped into a vast ocean." This is the awe [khashya] of the learned, as Allah the Exalted said: "Only those of His servants who have knowledge fear Allah." The general believers also have a share of this awe, but it is merely by imitation [taqlid]â€”it is like a child's fear of a snake, imitating his father. That is not based on insight [basira], so it is no wonder it weakens and vanishes quickly. Indeed, the child may see the snake-charmer proceed to take the snake, look at him, be deceived by him, and dare to take it, imitating him, just as he refrained from taking it by imitating his father. Imitative beliefs are generally weak, unless they are strengthened by constantly witnessing their confirming causes and by persisting in their requirementsâ€”in multiplying acts of obedience and avoiding sins for a long duration, continuously. Therefore, whoever ascends to the pinnacle of knowledge [ma'rifa] and knows Allah the Exalted, fears Him by necessity. He does not need a remedy to bring about fear, just as one who knows the lion and sees himself fallen into its claws does not need a remedy to bring fear to his heart. Rather, he fears it by necessity, whether he wills or not. For this reason, Allah the Exalted inspired to David, peace be upon him: "Fear Me as you fear the predatory lion." There is no means to bring about fear of the predatory lion except knowing the lion and knowing one has fallen into its claws. So he needs no means. Thus, whoever knows Allah the Exalted knows that He does what He wills and does not care, and He decrees what He desires and does not fear. He brought the angels near without a prior means, and He banished Iblis without a past crime. Rather, His attribute is what His statement translates: "These are in Paradise, and I do not care."

And as for the fear of the father, it is from insight and knowledge of the snake's attribute, its poison, its characteristic, the lion's ferocity, its assault, and its lack of concern. And as for the fear of the son, it is his belief by mere imitation because he has good opinion of his father and knows that he does not fear except from a fearful cause in himself, so he knows that the lion is fearful but does not know its aspect. And if you understand this example, then know that the fear of God the Exalted is on two levels: one is the fear of His punishment, and the second is the fear from Him. As for the fear from Him, it is the fear of the scholars and the possessors of hearts (Qulub) who know from His attributes what necessitates awe, fear, and caution, those who are aware of the secret of His saying the Exalted: 'And Allah warns you of Himself' and His saying the Mighty and Majestic: 'Fear Allah as He should be feared.' And as for the first, it is the fear of the general creation, and it is attained by the foundation of belief in Paradise and Hell and that they are two recompenses for obedience and disobedience, and its weakness is due to heedlessness and the weakness of belief. And indeed, heedlessness is removed by reminding and admonition and persistence in thought about the terrors of the Day of Resurrection and the types of punishment in the Hereafter, and it is also removed by looking at those who fear and keeping their company and observing their states. And if observation is missed, then hearing is not devoid of effect. And as for the second, which is the higher, it is that God is the One to be feared, meaning that the servant fears the veil from Him and hopes for closeness to Him.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Companionship
And it is not hidden that the fruit of good character (Khuluq) is affection (Alfah) and the cutting off of estrangement (Wahshah), and whenever the source is good, the fruit is good. And how could it be otherwise when there has come in praise of affection (Alfah) itself, especially when the bond is piety (Taqwa) and religion (Deen) and love of Allah, from the verses (Ayah), reports (Akhbar), and traditions (Athar) what is sufficient and convincing. Allah the Exalted said, manifesting His great favor upon creation with the blessing of affection (Alfah): 'If you had spent all that is in the earth, you could not have brought their hearts together; but Allah brought them together.' And He said: 'So you became, by His favor, brothers' meaning through affection (Alfah). Then He censured division (Tafarruq) and warned against it, so He, the Mighty, the Speaker, said: 'And hold fast, all of you, to the rope (Habl) of Allah and do not be divided (Tafarraqa) so that you may be guided.'

And the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "When the people of the Fire [ahl al-nar] gather in the Fire, and with them, whomever God wills from the people of the Qiblah [ahl al-qiblah], the disbelievers [kuffar] will say to the Muslims: 'Were you not Muslims?' They will say: 'Yes.' So they will say: 'What did your Islam [islam] avail you, since you are with us in the Fire?' They will say: 'We had sins [dhunub], so we were taken by them.' Then God, Mighty and Majestic, hears what they said, and He commands that whoever was in the Fire from the people of the Qiblah be brought out, so they are brought out. When the disbelievers see that, they say: 'If only we had been Muslims, so we could be brought out as they were brought out.'" Then the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, recited: "Often those who disbelieve wish that they had been Muslims [muslimun]." And it is narrated that a Bedouin heard Ibn Abbas reciting: "And you were on the brink of a pit of the Fire [nar], so He saved you from it." So the Bedouin said: "By God, He did not save you from it while He intends to cast you into it!" So Ibn Abbas said: "Take it from one who is not a jurist [faqih]."

And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said regarding the verse 'And hold firmly to the rope (Habl) of Allah all together and do not become divided. And remember the favor (Ni'mah) of Allah upon you - when you were enemies and He brought your hearts (Qulub) together and you became, by His favor (Ni'mah), brothers. And you were on the edge (Shafa) of a pit of the Fire and He saved you from it. Thus does Allah make clear to you His verses (Ayat) that you may be guided': 'Indeed, Allah will single out a man from my community on the Day of Resurrection before all creation. He will spread out before him ninety-nine scrolls, each scroll as far as the eye can see. Then He will say: Do you deny anything from this? Have My recording angels wronged you? He will say: No, O Lord. He will say: Do you have any excuse? He will say: No, O Lord. He will say: Yes, indeed you have with Us one good deed, and there is no injustice upon you today. Then He will bring out a card on which is written: I bear witness that there is no deity but Allah and I bear witness that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah. He will say: O Lord, what is this card compared to these scrolls? He will say: You are not wronged. He said: Then the scrolls will be placed in one scale and the card in the other scale. He said: The scrolls will become light and the card will become heavy, for nothing is heavy alongside the name of Allah.'

Vol 2: Enjoining Good and Forbidding Evil
And the blame in neglecting and losing it, and what indicates that after the consensus of the community upon it and the indications of sound intellects toward it are the verses, reports, and traditions. As for the verses, then it is His saying, the Exalted: 'And let there be from you a community calling to the good and enjoining the recognized good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbidding the disapproved evil (al-Munkar), and those are the successful ones.' For in the verse is clarification of the obligation, for His saying, the Exalted, 'And let there be' is a command, and the apparent meaning of the command is obligation. And in it is clarification that the success (al-Falah) is tied to it, since He restricted and said, 'And those are the successful ones.' And in it is clarification that it is a collective obligation (Fard Kifayah), not an individual obligation (Fard 'Ayn), and that if a community undertakes it, the obligation falls from the others, since He did not say, 'Be all of you enjoiners of the recognized good,' but rather He said, 'And let there be from you a community.' So if, whenever one or a group undertakes it, the burden falls from the others, and the success (al-Falah) is specified for those who undertake it directly, and even if all of creation refrains from it, the burden encompasses all those capable of it without fail.

a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Seclusion
Mention of the arguments of those inclined toward mixing/social interaction and the aspect of their weakness. These people argued with His saying, the Exalted: 'And do not be like those who divided and differed after the clear proofs had come to them' (the verse) and with His saying, the Exalted: 'And He united between your hearts (Qulub). You became, by His grace, brothers' (3:103). And this is weak because what is intended by it is the division of opinions and the difference of schools of thought in the meanings of the Book of Allah and the foundations of the Sharia. And what is intended by unity (Al-Ulfah) is the removal of the hidden enmities from the chests (Sudur), which are the causes that stir up seditions and move disputes. And seclusion (Al-Uzlah) does not contradict that.

But as for those whose faces will turn white, [they will be] within the mercy of Allah. They will abide therein eternally.
These are the verses of Allah. We recite them to you, [O Muhammad], in truth; and Allah wants no injustice to the worlds.
To Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. And to Allah will [all] matters be returned.

You are the best nation produced [as an example] for mankind. You enjoin what is right and forbid what is wrong and believe in Allah. If only the People of the Scripture had believed, it would have been better for them. Among them are believers, but most of them are defiantly disobedient.

From you, it was said: 'Rather from them, O Messenger of Allah.' He said: 'No, rather from you, because you find helpers for the good (al-Khayr), and they do not find helpers for it.' And Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, was asked about the interpretation (tafsir) of this verse (ayah). He said: 'This is not its time; today it is accepted, but it has nearly come that its time will come: you enjoin the good (al-Ma'ruf) and such and such will be done to you, and you say, but it is not accepted from you. Then at that time, upon yourselves, it does not harm you if someone goes astray when you are guided.' And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'You must enjoin the good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the evil (al-Munkar), or Allah will empower over you the worst of you, then the best of you will supplicate, but they will not be answered.' The hadith: 'You must enjoin the good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the evil (al-Munkar), or Allah will empower over you the worst of you, then the best of you will supplicate, but they will not be answered.' Al-Bazzar narrated it from the hadith of Umar ibn al-Khattab, and al-Tabarani in al-Awsat from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah, and both are weak. And al-Tirmidhi has from the hadith of Hudhayfah something similar, except he said: 'Or it is nearly that Allah sends upon you a punishment from Him, then you supplicate to Him, but He does not respond to you.' He said: 'This hadith is hasan; its meaning is that their awe falls from the eyes of the evildoers, so they do not fear them.' And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'O people, indeed Allah says: You must enjoin the good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the evil (al-Munkar) before you supplicate, then you will not be answered.' Vol 2: Enjoining Good and Forbidding Evil
And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'You must command the good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the evil (al-Munkar), or Allah will empower the worst among you over you, then the best among you will supplicate but will not be answered.' The hadith 'You must command the good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the evil (al-Munkar), or Allah will empower the worst among you over you, then the best among you will supplicate but will not be answered' is reported by Al-Bazzar from the hadith of Umar ibn Al-Khattab and Al-Tabarani in Al-Awsat from the hadith of Abu Hurairah, and both are weak. And Al-Tirmidhi reports from the hadith of Hudhayfah similarly, except that he said: 'Or Allah will soon send upon you a punishment from Him, then you will call upon Him but He will not respond to you.' He said this hadith is good in meaning: their awe falls from the eyes of the evildoers, so they do not fear them. And he (peace be upon him) said: 'O people, Allah says: You must command the good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the evil (al-Munkar) before you supplicate but are not answered.' The hadith 'O people, Allah the Exalted says: You must command the good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the evil (al-Munkar) before you supplicate but are not answered' is reported by Ahmad and Al-Bayhaqi from the hadith of Aisha with the wording 'Command and forbid,' and it is in Ibn Majah without attributing it to the speech of Allah the Exalted, and in its chain there is weakness. And he (peace be upon him) said: 'What are the deeds of righteousness (al-Birr) compared to striving in the path of Allah (al-Jihad fi Sabil Allah) except like a drop in a vast ocean? And what are all the deeds of righteousness (al-Birr) and striving in the path of Allah (al-Jihad fi Sabil Allah) compared to commanding the good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbidding the evil (al-Munkar) except like a drop in a vast ocean?' The hadith 'What are the deeds of righteousness (al-Birr) compared to striving in the path of Allah (al-Jihad fi Sabil Allah) except like a drop in a vast ocean? And what are all the deeds of righteousness (al-Birr) and striving in the path of Allah (al-Jihad fi Sabil Allah) compared to commanding the good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbidding the evil (al-Munkar) except like a drop in a vast ocean?' Then Allah the Exalted said: 'You are the best community (Ummah) brought forth for mankind: you command the good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the evil (al-Munkar), and you believe in Allah. And if the People of the Book (Ahl al-Kitab) had believed, it would have been better for them. Among them are the believers (al-Mu'minun), but most of them are the defiantly disobedient (al-Fasiqun).'

Vol 2: Enjoining Good and Forbidding Evil
And Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) was asked about the interpretation of this verse, and he said: 'This is not its time; today it is accepted, but it has almost come that its time will come when you command the Good (al-Ma'ruf) and such and such will be done to you, and you will say, but it will not be accepted from you. Then at that time, upon yourselves (it is) - "He who goes astray will not harm you if you are guided." And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "You must command the Good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the Evil (al-Munkar), or Allah will empower over you the worst among you, then the best among you will supplicate but will not be answered." The hadith: "You must command the Good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the Evil (al-Munkar), or Allah will empower over you the worst among you, then the best among you will supplicate but will not be answered" - Al-Bazzar narrated it from the hadith of Umar ibn al-Khattab, and Al-Tabarani in Al-Awsat from the hadith of Abu Hurairah, and both are weak. And Al-Tirmidhi has from the hadith of Hudhayfah something similar, except that he said: "Or it is almost that Allah will send upon you a punishment from Him, then you will call upon Him but He will not respond to you." He said: This hadith is hasan; its meaning is that their awe falls from the eyes of the evildoers, so they do not fear them. And he (peace be upon him) said: "O people, indeed Allah says: 'You must command the Good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the Evil (al-Munkar) before you supplicate but are not answered.'" The hadith: "O people, indeed Allah, the Exalted, says: 'You must command the Good (al-Ma'ruf) and forbid the Evil (al-Munkar) before you supplicate but are not answered'" - Ahmad and Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from the hadith of Aishah with the wording: 'Command and forbid,' and it is in Ibn Majah without attributing it to the speech of Allah, the Exalted, and in its chain there is weakness. And he (peace be upon him) said: "What are the deeds of Righteousness (al-Birr) compared to Striving (Jihad) in the Path (Sabil) of Allah except like a drop in a vast ocean? And what are all the deeds of Righteousness (al-Birr) and Striving (Jihad) in the Path (Sabil) of Allah compared to Commanding the Good (al-Ma'ruf) and Forbidding the Evil (al-Munkar) except like a drop in a vast ocean?" The hadith: "What are the deeds of Righteousness (al-Birr) compared to Striving (Jihad) in the Path (Sabil) of Allah except like a drop in a vast ocean?" - Abu Mansur Al-Daylami narrated it in Musnad Al-Firdaws, limiting it to the first part of the hadith of Jabir with its chain.

Vol 2: Enjoining Good and Forbidding Evil
Indeed, they are not all alike. Among the People of the Book is an upright community [ummah qa'imah] who recite the verses of Allah [ayat Allah] during the hours of the night, and they prostrate. They believe in Allah and the Last Day [al-Yawm al-Akhir], and they enjoin what is right [al-ma'ruf] and forbid what is wrong [al-munkar], and they hasten to good deeds. And those are among the righteous [al-salihin]. Thus, He did not testify to their righteousness [al-salah] merely by their faith in Allah and the Last Day until He added to it: enjoining what is right and forbidding what is wrong.

a.g: And whatever good they do - never will it be removed from them. And Allah is Knowing of the righteous.
Indeed, those who disbelieve - never will their wealth or their children avail them against Allah at all, and those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally.

The example of what they spend in this worldly life is like that of a wind containing frost which strikes the harvest of a people who have wronged themselves and destroys it. And Allah has not wronged them, but they wrong themselves.

O you who have believed, do not take as intimates those other than yourselves, for they will not spare you [any] ruin. They wish you would have hardship. Hatred has already appeared from their mouths, and what their breasts conceal is greater. We have certainly made clear to you the signs, if you will use reason.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
The first cause: enmity and hatred, and this is the strongest cause of envy (Hasad), for whoever is harmed by a person due to some cause and is opposed in a desire in some manner, his heart hates him and becomes angry with him, and rancor (Haqd) becomes firmly rooted in his soul (Nafs). And rancor necessitates seeking revenge and retaliation; if the hater is unable to take revenge himself, he loves that time take revenge for him, and perhaps he attributes that to the honor of his self (Nafs) with Allah the Exalted. So whenever a calamity befalls his enemy, he rejoices at it and thinks it is a reward for him from Allah for his hatred and that it is for his sake; and whenever a blessing befalls him, it grieves him because it is contrary to his desire, and perhaps it occurs to him that he has no status with Allah since He did not avenge him from his enemy who harmed him but rather bestowed favor upon him. In summary, envy necessitates hatred and enmity and does not separate from them, and the utmost limit of piety (Taqwa) is not to transgress and to dislike that from his self (Nafs). As for hating a person and then being equal at his joy and sorrow, this is not possible, and this is among what Allah the Exalted described the disbelievers with, meaning envy with enmity, when Allah the Exalted said: 'And when they meet you, they say, "We believe," but when they are alone, they bite their fingertips at you in rage. Say, "Die in your rage. Indeed, Allah is Knowing of that within the breasts." If good touches you, it distresses them' the verse. And likewise He said: 'They wish you would have hardship. Hatred has already shown from their mouths, and what their breasts conceal is greater.' And envy due to hatred may lead to dispute and fighting and consuming one's lifetime in removing the blessing through schemes, slander, and exposing secrets and what follows that course.

And what sin exceeds your hatred for the comfort of a Muslim without there being any harm to you from it? And to this the Quran pointed with His saying: "If a good thing touches you, it distresses them; and if a bad thing befalls you, they rejoice at it." And this rejoicing is gloating (Schadenfreude), and envy (Hasad) and gloating (Shamata) are concomitant.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
Know that the one who harms is naturally hated, and if someone harms you, you cannot help but hate them generally. So if a blessing (Ni'mah) becomes easy for them, you cannot help but dislike it for them until the good state of your enemy and his bad state become equal to you. Rather, you continuously perceive in the Soul (Nafs) a distinction between them, and Satan continuously contends with you towards envy (Hasad) for him. But if that becomes strong in you until it incites you to manifest envy (Hasad) by word or action such that it is known from your outward appearance by your voluntary actions, then you are an envious sinner by your envy (Hasad). And if you completely restrain your outward appearance, but in your inner self you love the removal of the blessing (Ni'mah) and there is no dislike in your Soul (Nafs) for this state, then you are also an envious sinner, because envy (Hasad) is an attribute of the Heart (Qalb), not an attribute of action. Allah the Exalted said: "Nor will they find in their chests a need of that which they have been given" (Quran 59:9), and He the Almighty said: "They wish that you would disbelieve as they have disbelieved, so you would be equal" (Quran 4:89), and He said: "If good touches you, it distresses them" (Quran 3:120). As for the action, it is backbiting and lying, and it is an act emanating from envy (Hasad) and is not the essence of envy (Hasad). Rather, the place of envy (Hasad) is the Heart (Qalb), not the limbs. Yes, this envy (Hasad) is not an injustice that one seeks to make permissible, but it is a sin between you and Allah the Exalted. And seeking permissibility is only required from the apparent causes on the limbs. So if you restrain your outward appearance and compel with that your Heart (Qalb) to dislike what naturally emanates from it of loving the removal of the blessing (Ni'mah) until it is as if you detest your Soul (Nafs) for what is in its nature, so that dislike is from the side of the intellect in opposition to the inclination from the side of nature, then you have fulfilled the obligation upon you. And in most cases, no more than this enters under your choice. As for changing the nature so that the one who harms and the one who does good become equal to him, and his joy or grief over what becomes easy for them of blessing (Ni'mah) or what befalls them of calamity becomes equal, this is something that nature does not comply with as long as one is attentive to the shares of the worldly life, unless one becomes absorbed in Allah the Exalted like the intoxicated, passionate one. Then his affair may end with his Heart (Qalb) not paying attention to the details of the states of the servants, but rather looking at all with one eye, which is the eye of mercy, and seeing all as servants of Allah and their actions as actions of Allah, and seeing them as subjugated. And if that is, it is like fleeting lightning that does not last. Then the Heart (Qalb) returns after that to its nature and the

And when his incisor was broken and he was wounded on the day of Uhud, and the blood was flowing on his face while he was wiping the blood and saying: 'How can a people succeed who have stained the face of their Prophet with blood while he is calling them to their Lord?' The hadith of his incisor being broken (peace be upon him) on the day of Uhud - the hadith concerning the revelation of 'Not for you is any part of the matter' - Muslim narrated it from the hadith of Anas, and Bukhari mentioned it as a suspended narration. Indeed, know that the reality of good character [husn al-khuluq] and bad character [su' al-khuluq]â€”people have spoken about the reality of good character and what it is, yet they did not address its true essence; rather, they addressed its fruits. Then they did not encompass all of its fruits, but each one mentioned from its fruits what occurred to him and what was present in his mind, and they did not devote care to mentioning its definition and its reality with all of its fruits in detail and comprehensiveness. And lifting the veil from the reality is more important than transmitting differing statements. So We say: *Khulq* and *khalq* are two expressions used together. It is said: 'So-and-so is of good *khulq* and *khalq*'â€”meaning good in the inward [batin] and the outward [zahir]. For *khalq* is intended as the outward form, and *khulq* is intended as the inward form. That is because the human is composed of a body perceived by sight [basar] and of a spirit [ruh] and soul [nafs] perceived by insight [basira]. And each one of them has a state [haya] and a form [sura], either ugly or beautiful. And the soul [nafs] perceived by insight is of greater stature than the body perceived by sight. And for that, Allah magnified its affair by attributing it to Himself when He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, I am creating a human from clay. So when I have proportioned him and breathed into him of My spirit [ruh], then fall down to him in prostration." Thus He pointed out that the body is ascribed to the clay and the spirit [ruh] to the Lord of the worlds. And what is intended by spirit [ruh] and soul [nafs] in this context is one. Thus, character [khuluq] is an expression for a firmly established state [haya] in the soul [nafs], from which actions issue forth with ease and facility, without need for thought and deliberation. If the state is such that beautiful, praiseworthy actionsâ€”by reason [aql] and by law [shar']â€”issue forth from it, that state is called good character [khuluq hasan]. And if what issues forth from it are ugly actions, the state which is the source is called bad character [khuluq sayyi']. And We only said it is a firmly established state because one from whom spending wealth occurs rarely due to a transient need is not said to have the character [khuluq] of generosity, unless that becomes firmly established in his soul [nafs] with firm rootedness. And We stipulated that actions issue forth from it with ease. And He, the Exalted, said: "And those who restrain anger [ghayz] and pardon the people," and He did not say 'those devoid of anger.' Thus, He returned anger [ghadab] and desire [shahwa] to a state of moderation [i'tidal] such that neither of them overpowers the intellect [aql] nor overcomes it. Rather, the intellect [aql] is the controller of them and the dominant over themâ€”this is possible. And that is what is intended by changing character [taghyir al-khuluq], for perhaps desire [shahwa] may gain mastery over a person such that his intellect [aql] is not strong enough to repel it, and he proceeds to indulge in indecencies. And through spiritual discipline [riyada] it returns to a state of moderation [i'tidal]. Thus, it indicates that this is possible, and experience [tajriba] and observation [mushahada] indicate that with an indication in which there is no doubt.

And what is required in the attribute of anger is good zeal, such that it is free from recklessness and cowardice altogether. In summary, that one be strong in his Soul (Nafs) and with his strength submissive to the intellect. Therefore, Allah the Exalted said, "Severe against the disbelievers, merciful among themselves." He described them with severity, and severity indeed issues from anger, and if anger were nullified, jihad would be nullified. How can one intend to uproot desire and anger completely when the Prophets, peace be upon them, were not free from that, as He (the Prophet) said, "I am only a human; I get angry as humans get angry." "And when something he disliked was said in his presence, he would get angry until his cheeks reddened, but he would only speak truth, so peace be upon him, his anger would not take him away from truth." And Allah the Exalted said, "And those who restrain anger and pardon the people." And He did not say, "And those who lack anger." So return anger and desire to the limit of moderation such that neither of them overpowers the intellect nor overcomes it, but rather the intellect is the regulator for them and the dominant over them is possible, and that is what is meant by changing the character, for sometimes desire may dominate a person such that his intellect is not strong enough to repel it, so he proceeds to indulgence in abominations. And through spiritual discipline (Riyada) it returns to the limit of moderation, so that indicates that it is possible, and experience and observation indicate that with an indication in which there is no doubt.

And he (the Prophet) said: "Indeed, I seek forgiveness from Allah the Exalted and repent to Him seventy times a day." This despite that he (the Prophet) was forgiven what preceded of his sin and what followed. And he (the Prophet) said: "Indeed, a covering comes over my heart (Qalb) until indeed I seek forgiveness from Allah the Exalted one hundred times a day." And he (the Prophet) said: "Whoever says when he goes to his bed: 'I seek forgiveness from Allah the Great, there is no deity except Him, the Living, the Sustainer, and I repent to Him' three times, Allah forgives him his sins even if they were like the foam of the sea or the number of sand of 'Alaj or the number of leaves of trees or the number of days of the world." Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
And the Quran declares that God-consciousness (Taqwa) is the key to guidance and unveiling, and that is knowledge without learning. And Allah the Exalted said: 'And We have not created the heavens and the earth and what is between them except in truth and for a specified term. But those who disbelieve, from that of which they are warned, are turning away.' (46:3) He specified it for them. And He said: 'This is a clear statement for mankind and a guidance and an admonition for the God-conscious (Mut-taqeen).' And Abu Yazid and others used to say: 'The knowledgeable one is not he who memorizes from a book, for if he forgets what he memorized, he becomes ignorant. Rather, the knowledgeable one is he who takes his knowledge from his Lord whenever he wills, without memorization or study.' And this is the divine knowledge (Al-'Ilm Ar-Rabbani), and to it points His saying: 'And We taught him from Us a knowledge.' (18:65) Although all knowledge is from Him, but some of it is through the intermediaries of teaching the creation, so that is not called divine knowledge (Ladunni). Rather, the divine (Ladunni) is that which opens in the secret of the heart (Sirr Al-Qalb) without a customary cause from the outside.

a.g: So do not weaken and do not grieve, and you will be superior if you are [true] believers.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
And Allah the Exalted has said: 'And you are the superior ones if you are believers' as a preference for the believers over the Muslims, and what is intended by it is the believing knower (al-Mu'min al-'Arif) not the imitator (al-Muqallid). And He the Mighty and Majestic said: 'Allah raises those who have believed among you and those who were given knowledge by degrees.' So He intended here by 'those who have believed' those who have verified/affirmed (Sadaqu) without knowledge, and distinguished them from those who were given knowledge. And that indicates that the name 'believer' (al-Mu'min) applies to the imitator even if his verification/affirmation (Tasdiq) is not from insight (Bassirah) and unveiling (Kashf).

And these days [of varying conditions] We alternate among the people so that Allah may make evident those who believe and [may] take to Himself from among you martyrs - and Allah does not like the wrongdoers -
And that Allah may purify the believers [through trials] and destroy the disbelievers.
Or do you think that you will enter Paradise while Allah has not yet made evident those of you who fight in His cause and made evident those who are steadfast?
And you had certainly wished for martyrdom before you encountered it, and you have [now] seen it [before you] while you were looking on.

Muhammad is not but a messenger. [Other] messengers have passed on before him. So if he was to die or be killed, would you turn back on your heels [to unbelief]? And he who turns back on his heels will never harm Allah at all; but Allah will reward the grateful.

a.g: And it is not [possible] for one to die except by permission of Allah at a decree determined. And whoever desires the reward of this world - We will give him thereof; and whoever desires the reward of the Hereafter - We will give him thereof. And we will reward the grateful.

And how many a prophet [fought and] with him fought many religious scholars. But they never lost assurance due to what afflicted them in the cause of Allah, nor did they weaken or submit. And Allah loves the steadfast.
And their words were not but that they said, "Our Lord, forgive us our sins and the excess [committed] in our affairs and plant firmly our feet and give us victory over the disbelieving people."
So Allah gave them the reward of this world and the good reward of the Hereafter. And Allah loves the doers of good.
O you who have believed, if you obey those who disbelieve, they will turn you back on your heels, and you will [then] become losers.
But Allah is your protector, and He is the best of helpers.

We will cast terror into the hearts of those who disbelieve for what they have associated with Allah of which He had not sent down [any] authority. And their refuge will be the Fire, and wretched is the residence of the wrongdoers.

And Allah had certainly fulfilled His promise to you when you were killing the enemy by His permission until [the time] when you lost courage and fell to disputing about the order [given by the Prophet] and disobeyed after He had shown you that which you love. Among you are some who desire this world, and among you are some who desire the Hereafter. Then he turned you back from them [defeated] that He might test you. And He has already forgiven you, and Allah is the possessor of bounty for the believers.

And Allah is [fully] Acquainted with what you do.

Then after distress, He sent down upon you security [in the form of] drowsiness, overcoming a faction of you, while another faction worried about themselves, thinking of Allah other than the truth - the thought of ignorance, saying, "Is there anything for us [to have done] in this matter?" Say, "Indeed, the matter belongs completely to Allah." They conceal within themselves what they will not reveal to you. They say, "If there was anything we could have done in the matter, some of us would not have been killed right here." Say, "Even if you had been inside your houses, those decreed to be killed would have come out to their death beds." [It was] so that Allah might test what is in your breasts and purify what is in your hearts. And Allah is Knowing of that within the breasts.

And it is said: Five character traits are from the signs of the scholars of the Hereafter, understood from five verses from the Book of Allah the Exalted: fear (Khushya), humility (Khushu'), humility/lowliness (Tawadu'), good character (Husn al-Khuluq), and preferring the Hereafter over the world, which is asceticism (Zuhd). And as for humility/lowliness, it is from His saying the Exalted: 'And lower your wing to the believers' (Al-Hajj: 88). And as for good character, it is from His saying the Exalted: 'So by mercy from Allah, you were gentle with them' (Al 'Imran: 159). And as for asceticism, it is from His saying the Exalted: 'But those who were given knowledge said, "Woe to you! The reward of Allah is better for he who has believed and done righteousness"' (Al-Qasas: 80).

And He, the Exalted and Majestic, said: "Indeed, Allah loves those who rely (upon Him) (Al-Mutawakkilin)." And how great is a station marked with the love of Allah, the Exalted, its possessor, and encompassed by the sufficiency of Allah, the Exalted, its companion. So whoever from Allah, the Exalted, is his sufficiency and his suffices and his lover and his protector: then he has attained the great success, for the beloved is not punished nor distanced nor veiled. And He, the Exalted, said: "Is not Allah sufficient for His servant?" So the seeker of sufficiency from other than Him and the abandoner of reliance (Tawakkul) is the one who denies this verse. For it is a question in the form of an interrogation with the truth, like His saying, the Exalted: "Has there not come upon man a period of time when he was not a thing mentioned?" And He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "And whoever relies upon Allah, then indeed Allah is Mighty, Wise." Meaning Mighty, He does not humiliate the one who seeks refuge with Him, nor does He waste the one who clings to His side and resorts to His protection and sanctuary, and Wise, He does not fall short in managing the one who relies upon His management. And He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, those whom you invoke besides Allah are servants like you." He clarifies that everything other than Allah, the Exalted, is a subjugated servant. His need is like your need, so how can one rely upon him? And He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, those whom you worship besides Allah do not possess for you provision, so seek provision from Allah and worship Him." And He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "And to Allah belong the treasures of the heavens and the earth, but the hypocrites do not understand." And He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "He arranges the matter; there is no intercessor except after His permission." And everything mentioned in the Quran from the Oneness (Tawhid) is an alert to cutting off observation.

a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
And all of that is by the Decree (Qada) and Predestination (Qadar) of Allah. So whomever Allah wills to guide, He expands his chest for Islam, and whomever He wills to misguide, He makes his chest tight and constricted as if he were ascending into the sky. 'If Allah helps you, none can overcome you; and if He forsakes you, who is there after Him that can help you? And upon Allah let the believers rely.' He is the Guide (Al-Hadi) and the Misguider (Al-Mudill); He does what He wills and decrees what He intends. There is no repeller of His decree and no reverser of His judgment. He created Paradise and created for it its people, so He employed them with obedience, and He created Hellfire and created for it its people, so He employed them with disobedience. And He made known to the creation the sign of the people of Paradise and the people of Hellfire, so He said: 'Indeed, the righteous will be in bliss, and indeed, the wicked will be in a Blazing Fire.' Then He, the Exalted, said in what is narrated from His Prophet, peace be upon him: 'These are in Paradise, and I do not care, and these are in Hellfire, and I do not care.'

a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 4: Watchfulness and Self-Examination
And He (Exalted) said: 'On the day when Allah will resurrect them all together, then He will inform them of what they did. Allah has kept account of it, while they forgot it; and Allah is Witness over all things.' And He (Exalted) said: 'On that day, the people will proceed in separate groups to be shown their deeds. So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, and whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it.' And He (Exalted) said: 'Then every soul (Nafs) will be fully compensated for what it earned, and they will not be wronged.' And He (Exalted) said: 'On the day when every soul (Nafs) will find what it did of good present [before it], and what it did of evil, it will wish that between itself and that [evil] was a great distance. And Allah warns you of Himself.' And He (Exalted) said: 'And know that Allah knows what is within your souls (Anfus), so beware of Him.' So the possessors of insight (Arbab al-Basa'ir) from among the servants recognized that Allah (Exalted) is lying in wait for them, and that they will be scrutinized in the accounting and will be demanded for the atom's weights of the passing thoughts (Khatarat) and glances (Lahazat). And they realized that nothing will save them from these dangers except adhering to self-accounting (Muhasabah) and sincerity in self-observation (Muraqabah), and demanding from the soul (Nafs) in the breaths (Anfas) and movements, and accounting it for the passing thoughts (Khatarat) and glances (Lahazat). For whoever accounts his soul (Nafs) before being accounted for, his accounting on the Day of Resurrection (Qiyamah) will be lightened, and his answer will be present at the questioning, and his return and outcome will be good. And whoever does not account his soul (Nafs), his regrets will persist, and his pauses in the courtyards of the Day of Resurrection (Qiyamah) will be prolonged, and his evil deeds will lead him to disgrace and contempt.

a.g: Certainly did Allah confer [great] favor upon the believers when He sent among them a Messenger from themselves, reciting to them His verses and purifying them and teaching them the Book and wisdom, although they had been before in manifest error.

Why [is it that] when a [single] disaster struck you [on the day of Uhud], although you had struck [the enemy in the battle of Badr] with one twice as great, you said, "From where is this?" Say, "It is from yourselves." Indeed, Allah is over all things competent.
And what struck you on the day the two armies met was by permission of Allah that He might make evident the [true] believers.

And that He might make evident those who are hypocrites. For it was said to them, "Come, fight in the way of Allah or [at least] defend." They said, "If we had known [there would be] fighting, we would have followed you." They were nearer to disbelief that day than to faith, saying with their mouths what was not in their hearts. And Allah is most Knowing of what they conceal -
Those who said about their brothers while sitting [at home], "If they had obeyed us, they would not have been killed." Say, "Then prevent death from yourselves, if you should be truthful."
And never think of those who have been killed in the cause of Allah as dead. Rather, they are alive with their Lord, receiving provision,

There is no greater devotion (Tajarrud) for Allah than that, and for that reason the matter of martyrdom is elevated, and there has come regarding it virtues that are innumerable.
