So fear of the future, when Allah has given you sustenance for your day for you and your dependents, is only from weakness of certainty (Yaqin) and listening to the intimidation of Satan (Shaytan). And Allah the Exalted has said: "So do not fear them and fear Me if you are believers." And He the Mighty and Majestic has said: "Satan promises you poverty and commands you to immorality (Fahsha), while Allah promises you forgiveness from Him and bounty." And asking (Sual) is from the immorality (Fahsha) that is permitted by necessity, and the state of one who asks for a need deferred beyond his day, even if it is from what is needed within the year, is more severe than the state of one who possesses inherited wealth and saves it for a need beyond the year. Both are permissible in the apparent legal opinion (Fatwa), but they stem from love of the world (Dunya), long hope (Tul al-Amal), and lack of trust in the bounty of Allah. And this characteristic is from the principal destroyers (Ummahat al-Muhlikat). We ask Allah for good success through His gentleness and generosity.

And the cure for this delusion is knowing the signs of honor and disgrace either through insight or through imitation. As for insight, it is by knowing how turning toward worldly desires distances from Allah and how distancing from them brings closer to Allah, and one perceives that through inspiration in the stations of the knowers (Al-Arifin) and the friends (Al-Awliya), and its explanation is among the sciences of unveiling and is not suitable for the science of transaction. "And as for knowing it through the way of imitation and belief," it is to have faith in the Book of Allah the Exalted and believe His Messenger. And He the Exalted has said: "Do they think that what We extend to them of wealth and children, We hasten for them in good things? Rather, they do not perceive." And He the Exalted said: "We will gradually lead them [to destruction] from where they do not know." And He the Exalted said: "We opened to them the gates of every thing until, when they rejoiced in that which they were given, We seized them suddenly, and at once they were in despair." And in the interpretation of His saying the Exalted "We will gradually lead them [to destruction] from where they do not know," it is that whenever they commit a sin, We grant them a blessing to increase their delusion. And He the Exalted said: "We only extend time for them that they may increase in sin." And He the Exalted said: "And never think that Allah is unaware of what the wrongdoers do. ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
If you say: How can I rejoice when I see a group whose disobedience (ma'siyyah) has increased beyond my disobedience, yet they have not been afflicted with what I have been afflicted with, even the disbelievers (kuffar). Know that for the disbeliever, what is greater has been stored away, and he is only given respite so that he may increase in sin (ithm) and his punishment (iqab) may be prolonged, as Allah the Exalted said: 'And let not those who disbelieve think that Our granting them respite is good for themselves. We only grant them respite so that they may increase in sin, and for them is a humiliating punishment.' As for the disobediences (ma'asi), from where do you know that in the world there is one who is more disobedient than him? And perhaps a thought (khatir) with bad manners (su' adab) towards Allah the Exalted and His attributes is greater and more severe than drinking wine (khamr), fornication (zina), and all other disobediences with the limbs (jawarih). Therefore, Allah the Exalted said about its like: 'And you consider it trivial, while with Allah it is great.' So from where do you know that others are more disobedient than you? Then perhaps his punishment has been delayed to the Hereafter (Akhirah) and your punishment hastened in this world (Dunya), so why do you not thank Allah the Exalted for that? And this is the third aspect in thankfulness (shukr), which is that there is no punishment except that it could be imagined to be delayed to the Hereafter. The afflictions (masa'ib) of this world are consoled by other means that lighten the affliction, so its impact is lessened. The affliction of the Hereafter endures, and if it does not endure, there is no way to alleviate it through consolation, since the means of consolation are completely cut off in the Hereafter from the tormented ones. And whoever's punishment is hastened in this world is not punished a second time, as the Messenger of Allah ï·º said: 'Indeed, when a servant (abd) commits a sin (dhanb) and is afflicted with hardship (shiddah) or trial (bala') in this world, Allah is more generous than to punish him a second time.' Fourth, that this affliction (musibah) and trial (baliyyah) were written for him in the Mother of the Book (Umm al-Kitab), and it was inevitable that it would reach him, and it has reached, and completion has occurred, and he has rested from some of it or all of it, so this is a blessing (ni'mah). Fifth, that its reward (thawab) is greater than it, for the afflictions of this world are paths to the Hereafter from one aspect.

Explanation of the Condemnation of Stinginess (Bakhil) Allah the Exalted said: "And whoever is protected from the greed (Shuh) of his Soul (Nafs) - then those are the successful ones." And He the Exalted said: "And let not those who are stingy (Yabkhaloon) with what Allah has given them of His bounty think it is good for them. Rather, it is evil for them. They will be collared with what they were stingy with on the Day of Resurrection." And He the Exalted said: "Those who are stingy and enjoin upon people stinginess and conceal what Allah has given them of His bounty." And He (peace be upon him) said: "Beware of greed (Shuh), for it destroyed those before you. It drove them to shed their blood and make lawful their prohibitions." [75] And He (peace be upon him) said: "Beware of greed, for it called those before you and they shed their blood, and it called them and they made lawful their prohibitions, and it called them and they severed their ties of kinship." [76] And He (peace be upon him) said: "The stingy one (Bakhil), the treacherous one, and the betrayer of bad character will not enter Paradise." [77] And in a narration: "Nor the tyrant." And in a narration: "Nor the one who reminds of his favor." And He (peace be upon him) said: "Three destructive things: obeyed greed, followed desire (Hawa), and a person's admiration of himself." [78] And He (peace be upon him) said: "Indeed, Allah hates three: the old fornicator, the stingy one who reminds of his favor, and the poor who is arrogant." [79] And He (peace be upon him) said: "The example of the spender and the stingy one is like two men upon whom are iron shirts from their chests to their collarbones. And Sa'd ibn Bilal said: On the Day of Resurrection, two men are commanded to be brought out from the Fire, then Allah, Blessed and Exalted, says: 'That is because of what your hands have sent forth, and that Allah is not unjust to the servants (3:182).' And some of the righteous (Salihin) said: While I was walking on a journey of mine, I turned to a tree to rest under it, and behold, I saw an elder who had approached me. So I said: And in what comes after death? He said: Whoever is certain of what comes after death, he rolls up the waistband of caution and does not have a resting place in this world (Dunya). Then he said: O You to whose face faces submit, whiten my face by looking at You, and fill my heart (Qalb) from the love (Mahabbah) for You, and save me from that reproach tomorrow with You, for indeed the time has come for me to feel shame (HayÄ') from You, and it has become time for me to return from turning away from You. Rise, he said: Were it not for Your forbearance (Hilm), my term would not have accommodated me, and were it not for Your pardon ('Afw), my hope would not have expanded in what is with You. Then he departed and left me. And they recited in this meaning: A thin body, sorrowful of the heart (Fu'Äd), you see him on a peak or in the valley's belly, lamenting over shameful sins, their weight disturbs the purity of sleep. Indeed, God Almighty said: "To make it clear to the people and not conceal it." And know that the easiest thing you have committed and the lightest burden you have borne is that you brought comfort to the loneliness of the wrongdoer [al-zalim] and smoothed the path of transgression [al-baghy] by drawing near to one who neither fulfilled a right nor abandoned a falsehood. When they drew you near, they took you as an axis [qutb] upon which the millstone of their injustice revolves, and as a bridge [jisr] over which they cross to their calamity, and as a ladder [sullam] upon which they ascend to their misguidance. And through you, they introduce doubt [al-shakk] to the people of knowledge [al-'ulama'], and through you, they ensnare the hearts [qulub] of the ignorant [al-jahilun]. So how trivial is what they built compared to what they destroyed for you, and how much they took from you in what they corrupted of your religion [din]! So what assures you that you are not among those about whom God Almighty said: "But there succeeded after them successors who neglected prayer..."? And indeed, you are dealing with One who is not ignorant, and an account is kept of you by One who is not heedless. So treat your religion [din], for sickness has entered it, and prepare your provision [zad], for a long journey [safar] has drawn near. And nothing is hidden from God of anything in the earth or in the heaven.

And it is not like that, Allah took the covenant upon the scholars. a.g: And never think that those who rejoice in what they have perpetrated and like to be praised for what they did not do - never think them [to be] in safety from the punishment, and for them is a painful punishment.
And to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth, and Allah is over all things competent.
Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs for those of understanding.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
Indeed, as Allah the Exalted has said: "Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs [ayat] for those of understanding [ulu al-albab]." And from 'Ata', he said: I set out one day, I and 'Ubayd ibn 'Umayr, to 'A'isha, may Allah be pleased with her. She spoke to us, and between us and her was a veil [hijab]. She said: "O 'Ubayd, what prevents you from visiting us?" He said: "The saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Visit infrequently, and love will increase.'" Ibn 'Umayr said: "So inform us of the most wondrous thing you saw from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him." She wept and said: "All of his affair was wondrous. He came to me in my night until his skin touched my skin. Then he said: 'Leave me to worship my Lord, the Mighty and Majestic.'" He rose to the water-skin and performed ablution from it. Then he stood to pray and wept until his beard became wet. Then he prostrated until the ground became wet. Then he lay on his side until Bilal came to give the call for the dawn prayer. He said: "O Messenger of Allah, what makes you weep when Allah has forgiven you your preceding and forthcoming sin?" He said: "Woe to you, O Bilal! And what prevents me from weeping when Allah the Exalted has revealed to me this night: 'Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs [ayat] for those of understanding [ulu al-albab].'" Then he said: "Woe to the one who recites it and does not reflect [yatafakkar] upon it."

Vol 4: Meditation
And the devils (Shayatin), and the Throne (Arsh), and the Footstool (Kursi), and other than that, and the field of thought (Fikr) in these things is what constricts and obscures, so let us turn to what is closer to understandings, which are the perceived things by the sense of sight, and that is the seven heavens and the earth and what is between them. So the heavens are observed with their stars, sun, moon, movement, and rotation in their rising and setting; and the earth is observed with what is in it of its mountains, minerals, rivers, seas, animals, and plants; and what is between the sky and the earth, which is the atmosphere, is perceived with its clouds, rains, snows, thunder, lightning, thunderbolts, meteors, and stormy winds. These are the observed genera from the heavens and the earth and what is between them, and every genus of them divides into species, and every species divides into sections, and each section branches into varieties, and there is no end to the branching and division of that in the difference of its attributes, forms, and apparent and hidden meanings, and all of that is a field of thought (Fikr). So not a particle moves in the heavens and the earth from inanimate matter (Jamaad), nor plant, nor animal, nor celestial sphere, nor star, except that Allah the Exalted is its mover, and in its movement is a wisdom (Hikmah) or two wisdoms, or ten, or a thousand wisdoms, all of that is a witness for Allah the Exalted to Oneness (Tawhid) and indicative of His majesty and greatness, and they are the signs (Ayat) indicating Him. And the Quran has come with urging to reflect (Tafakkur) on these signs (Ayat), as Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs (Ayat) for those of understanding (Ulul Albab).' And as He the Exalted said: 'And among His signs (Ayat) are...' from the beginning of the Quran to its end. So let us mention the manner of thought (Fikr) in some of the signs (Ayat). So from His signs (Ayat) is the human being (Insan) created from a sperm-drop (Nutfah), and the closest thing to you is your own self (Nafs), and in you are wonders indicating the greatness of Allah the Exalted that lifetimes would end in standing upon a tenth of its tenth while you are heedless (Ghaafil) of it. So O you who is heedless (Ghaafil) of his own self (Nafs) and ignorant of it, how do you aspire to know other than you when Allah the Exalted has commanded you to ponder (Tadabbur) in your self (Nafs) in His mighty Book, so He said: 'And in yourselves, do you not see?' And He mentioned that you are created from a filthy sperm-drop (Nutfah), so He said: 'Cursed is man; how disbelieving he is! From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop (Nutfah) He created him and destined for him; then He eased the way for him; then He causes him to die and puts him in his grave; then when He wills, He will resurrect him.' And He the Exalted said: 'And among His signs (Ayat) is that He created you from dust, then, at once, you are human beings dispersing [throughout the earth].' And He the Exalted said: 'Was he not a sperm-drop (Nutfah) from semen emitted? Then he was a clinging clot (Alaqah), and [Allah] created [his form] and proportioned [him].' And He the Exalted said: 'Did We not create you from a despised water (Maa' Mahin)? Then We placed it in a firm lodging (Qarar Makin) for a known extent.' And He said: 'Does man not consider that We created him from a sperm-drop (Nutfah)? Then at once he is a clear adversary.' And He said: 'Indeed, We created man from a sperm-drop mixture (Nutfah Amshaj).' Then He mentioned how He made the sperm-drop (Nutfah) a clinging clot (Alaqah), and the clinging clot (Alaqah) a lump of flesh (Mudghah), and the lump of flesh (Mudghah) bones, so He the Exalted said: 'And certainly did We create man from an extract of clay. Then We placed him as a sperm-drop (Nutfah) in a firm lodging (Qarar Makin). Then We made the sperm-drop (Nutfah) into a clinging clot (Alaqah)...' the verse. So the repetition of the mention of the sperm-drop (Nutfah) then...

Vol 4: Meditation
And the urging in the Book of Allah (God) the Exalted upon contemplation (Tadabbur) and consideration (I'tibar) and observation (Nadhar) and reflection (Iftikar) is abundant, and it is not hidden that thought (Fikr) is the key to the lights (Anwar) and the beginning of insight (Istibsar), and it is the net of sciences and the trap of knowledges and understandings. Most people have recognized its virtue and rank, but they have been ignorant of its reality (Haqiqah) and its fruit (Thamarah) and its source (Masdar) and its origin (Mawrid) and its course (Majra) and its arena (Masrah) and its path (Tariq) and its modality (Kayfiyyah), and they have not known how one reflects (Yatafakkar) and in what one reflects and why one reflects and what is sought by itâ€”is it desired for its own sake or for a fruit that is gained from it? If it is for a fruit, then what is that fruitâ€”is it from the sciences or from the states (Ahwal) or from both together? Uncovering all of that is important, and we will mention first the virtue of reflection (Tafakkur), then the reality of reflection and its fruit, then the courses of thought and its arenas, if Allah (God) the Exalted wills. The virtue of reflection: Allah (God) the Exalted has commanded reflection and contemplation in His Mighty Book in countless places and praised the reflectors, so He the Exalted said: 'Those who remember Allah (God) standing and sitting and on their sides and reflect in the creation of the heavens and the earth: Our Lord, You have not created this in vain.'

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
And the treatment of this deception (Ghurur) is either by affirmation of faith (Iman) or by proof (Burhan); as for affirmation by mere faith (Iman), it is to believe Allah the Exalted in His saying 'What is with you will be exhausted, and what is with Allah is enduring' and in His saying, the Mighty, the Majestic, 'And what is with Allah is better' and His saying 'And the Hereafter is better and more enduring' and His saying 'And the life of this world is nothing but the enjoyment of deception (Ghurur)' and His saying 'So let not the life of this world deceive you.' And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) informed groups of disbelievers of this, so they followed him, believed him, and had faith in him without demanding proof from him[3], and among them were those who said: 'I adjure you by Allah, has Allah sent you as a messenger?' He would say 'Yes,' so they would believe[4]. And this is the faith (Iman) of the common people, and it exits from deception (Ghurur), and this is placed in the position of a child believing his father that attending the school is better than attending the playground, even though he does not know the aspect of its being better. And as for knowledge by explanation and proof (Burhan), it is to know the aspect of corruption of this analogy (Qiyas) that the Satan (Shaytan) has organized in his heart (Qalb), for every deceived person has a cause for his deception (Ghurur), and that cause is evidence (Dalil), and every evidence (Dalil) is a type of analogy (Qiyas) that occurs in the soul (Nafs) and produces tranquility towards it, even if its possessor is not aware of it nor able to formulate it in the words of the scholars. So the analogy (Qiyas) that the Satan (Shaytan) has organized has two foundations: 'One' is that this world is cash (Naqd) and the Hereafter is credit (Nasi'ah), and this is correct; 'and the other' is his saying: Indeed, cash (Naqd) is better than credit (Nasi'ah), and this is the place of confusion (Talbis), for the matter is not so, rather if the cash (Naqd) is equal to the credit (Nasi'ah) in amount and purpose, then it is better, and if it is less than it, then the credit (Nasi'ah) is better. For the deceived disbeliever gives in his trade a dirham to take ten on credit (Nasi'ah) and does not consider that a loss, so how can he give Paradise, which is credit (Nasi'ah) in the Hereafter, for this world, which is cash (Naqd)? And this is from the greatest loss, and to this meaning Allah the Exalted alluded in His saying: 'But those who fear (Ittaqaw) their Lord, for them are gardens beneath which rivers flow, abiding therein forever, as hospitality from Allah. And what is with Allah is better for the righteous (Al-Abrar).' So He made clear that what is with Allah is better for the righteous (Al-Abrar), and the righteous (Al-Abrar) are those who fear (Ittaqaw), so whoever fears (Ittaqa) his Lord, for him is Paradise, and whoever does not fear (Ittaqa) his Lord, for him is the Fire, and this is the difference between cash (Naqd) and credit (Nasi'ah), for cash (Naqd) is this world and credit (Nasi'ah) is the Hereafter, so whoever prefers cash (Naqd) over credit (Nasi'ah) has incurred loss, and whoever prefers credit (Nasi'ah) over cash (Naqd) has gained profit, and this is the meaning of His saying, the Exalted, 'And what is with Allah is better.'

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
Indeed, the possessors of insight [arbab al-basa'ir] from among the servants have come to know that God, Exalted is He, lies in wait for them [lahum bil-mirsad], and that they will be called to account [yunaqqashun fil-hisab] and will be held to task for the weight of an atom [mithaqil adh-dharr] from passing thoughts [khawatir] and glances [lahthat]. And they have realized with certainty [tahaqqu] that nothing will save them from these perils except adhering to self-reckoning [luzum al-muhasaba] and sincerity in self-vigilance [sidq al-muraqaba], and holding the soul [nafs] to account for every breath [anfas] and movement [harakat], and reckoning with it for every passing thought [khawatir] and glance [lahthat]. For whoever holds his soul to account before he is held to account, his reckoning on the Day of Standing [al-qiyamah] will be lightened, his answer will be present when questioned, and his return and his final destination [ma'ab] will be good. And whoever does not hold his soul to account, his regrets [hasrat] will be prolonged, and his stations [waqfat] in the plains ['arasat] of the Day of Standing will be lengthy, and his misdeeds [sayyi'at] will lead him to disgrace and contempt. When this was unveiled to them, they knew that nothing would save them from it except obedience to God. And He had commanded them to patience [sabr] and steadfast vigilance [murabata], so He, Mighty and Majestic is He, said: "O you who believe, be patient, and vie in patience, and be steadfast, and fear God, that you may succeed." So they made their souls steadfastly vigilant [rabatu anfusahum] first through mutual pledging [al-musharata], then through self-vigilance [al-muraqaba], then through self-reckoning [al-muhasaba], then through self-chastisement [al-mu'aqaba], then through spiritual struggle [al-mujahada], then through self-admonition [al-mu'ataba]. Thus, for them in steadfast vigilance [al-murabata] were six stations [maqamat], and it is necessary to explain them, clarify their reality [haqiqa] and their virtue [fadila], and detail the works within them. The foundation of all that is self-reckoning [al-muhasaba], but every reckoning [hisab] comes after mutual pledging [musharata] and self-vigilance [muraqaba], and is followed, in case of loss [khusran], by self-admonition [mu'ataba] and self-chastisement [mu'aqaba].
